{{Infobox military person | name = Dimitrios Giatzis | image = | caption = | birth_date = 1891{{Greece Old Style dating}} | death_date = 1964 | birth_place = [[Lamia (city)|Lamia]] | death_place = | allegiance = {{flag|Greece|royal}} | branch = [[Hellenic Army]] | serviceyears = 1910–1941, 1945–1949 | rank = [[File:GR-Army-OF8-1937.svg|15px]] [[Lieutenant General]] | servicenumber = | commands = Chief of the [[Hellenic Army General Staff]] | battles = [[Balkan Wars]], [[Macedonian Front]], [[Greco-Turkish War of 1919–22]], [[Greco-Italian War]], [[Greek Civil War]] | battles_label = Wars | awards = [[Cross of Valour (Greece)|Cross of Valour in Gold]] (twice)<ref name="bio"/> | relations = | laterwork = }} '''Dimitrios Giatzis''' ({{lang-el|Δημήτριος Γιατζής}}, 1891–1964) was a senior [[Greece|Greek]] [[Hellenic Army|Army]] officer who held senior commands during the [[Greek Civil War]] of 1946–49, serving as commander of [[First Army (Greece)|First Army]] and Chief of the [[Hellenic Army General Staff]] in 1947–49.
== Life == Dimitrios Giatzis was born in [[Lamia (city)|Lamia]] in 1891, and enlisted in the Hellenic Army as a volunteer on 12 March 1910. Promoted to NCO, he took part in the [[Balkan Wars]] of 1912–13, and after studies at the NCO School was commissioned as an Infantry Second Lieutenant on 27 December 1914.<ref name="bio">{{cite book | title = Συνοπτική Ιστορία του Γενικού Επιτελείου Στρατού 1901–2001 | trans_title = A Concise History of the Hellenic Army General Staff 1901–2001 | year = 2001 | publisher = Army History Directorate | location = Athens | chapter=Αντιστράτηγος ΓΙΑΤΖΗΣ ΔΗΜΗΤΡΙΟΣ του ΧΡΗΣΤΟΥ, ΑΜ 7645 | page=168 | language = Greek}}</ref>
He subsequently fought on the [[Macedonian Front]] during [[World War I]] and in the [[Asia Minor Campaign]], first as a company commander and later as a staff officer, being promoted to Lieutenant in 1917 and to Captain in 1920.<ref name="bio"/> In the [[interwar]] period he served successively as battalion commander, chief of staff of the [[3rd Infantry Division (Greece)|3rd Infantry Division]], in the staff of [[II Army Corps (Greece)|II Army Corps]], in the Administrative Directorate of the Ministry for Military Affairs, commander of VI Border Sector (1938–40) and briefly chief of staff of the Infantry Inspectorate, before assuming command of III Infantry Brigade in September 1940. During this period he advanced to Major (1923), Lt. Colonel (1931), and Colonel (1935).<ref name="bio"/>
He led III Brigade during the first months of the [[Greco-Italian War]], and was appointed chief of infantry to [[8th Infantry Division (Greece)|8th Infantry Division]] in January 1941, a post in which he remained until the Greek capitulation following the [[German invasion of Greece]] in April.<ref name="bio"/>
Following liberation he joined the re-forming Army, and was named briefly commander of the 2nd National Guard Division in January 1945, before assuming command of the [[9th Infantry Division (Greece)|9th Infantry Division]] in the next month. On 15 May 1946, he was appointed commander of the newly re-established [[I Army Corps (Greece)|I Army Corps]] at Athens, and in February 1947 he became the first commander of the newly formed [[First Army (Greece)|First Army]] at [[Volos]]. He was moved to the post of Chief of the [[Hellenic Army General Staff]] on 1 November, a post he held concurrently with the ''ad hoc'' function of Commander-in–chief of the Army following the disbandment of First Army in March 1948, until 20 January 1949, when he retired from service at his own request.<ref name="bio"/>
Dimitrios Giatzis died in 1964.<ref name="bio"/>
